div.p:
1. VII. Attended the funeral of Constant Freeman, 4th. Auditor of the Treasury— At 11 this morning— The procession went from his house; to the Roman Catholic Church, where a short service was performed by the Curate, Matthews— Mr Frye with me— Returned to the Office— W. C. Bradley of Vermont; to recommend Slade for Freeman’s Office, and Hall for his place in the Department of State— Mr J. Finch an Englishman, with a Letter from J. Quincy— Wishes to visit P.U.S.Conway, the Delegate from Arkansas. About the Message, asking an Act to legalize Governor Miller’s Acts— I called at the President’s, with despatches, from H. Nelson, D. Sheldon, J. M. Forbes, and C. S. Todd and applications for the Office of fourth Auditor—the President had received many more— Among the rest from W. Findlay, Garnett and Foot of Connecticut. P.U.S. desired me to despatch E. Wyer, as soon as possible. Returned to the Office, found Farrelly; with six or seven names Members of Congress from Pennsylvania; recommending General Alden— Farrelly talked much of politics— Said Benton, had
announced in Senate, he should make specific charges against N. Edwards—for something twenty years ago; in Kentucky— Before Edwards was Chief Justice there— Farrelly said he himself had attended all the A. B. party meetings last Winter, and spoke of Governor Findlay’s Administration in Pennsylvania, as very troublesome to those who supported it. He said Lowry and Forward were down, flat in Pennsylvania, for having attended the Caucus, but Markley might save himself by the Resolutions he had offered and by his vote for Jackson. Mr Reed, a member of the House from Massachusetts came with a Coll. Vinson, an Officer in the late War, who now applies for a place— Has been unfortunate in the whale fishery, at Nantucket— MrSibley came again to make enquiries for Strong, concerning Lieutt. Knowles of the Boston Frigate in 1777. Eve at home; writing— G. Sullivan, and afterwards Fuller came in— Governor Eustis has superseded Sullivan as Agent for the Massachusetts claim. But Sullivan relies upon the efficacy of his Letter to Eustis, which he has given express directions to have published. He has read it to the President who he says approves of it in toto— He has also read it to Mr Southard. Fuller was much incensed because the President’s Message was sent, without a previous consultation of the Delegations of Massachusetts and Maine— Or at least of that of Massachusetts—or at all Events of the Republican portion of the Massachusetts. I endeavoured to appease him, by suggesting the objections there had been to taking that course— Holmes and Chandler of Maine, in league with King. The two Massachusetts Senators, with Webster, and six other members of the House, federalists, who must oppose the principle upon which the Message is founded— Fuller perceived the force of these remarks, and finally said he would consult with the Republicans of the Delegation, as to what is now to be done— Fuller read me a Letter from Munro publisher of the Baltimore Patriot— His fears that my friends will desert me for Crawford. W. King travels on to Maine, preaching this doctrine as he goes— I desired Fuller to attend to the equalizing in the new Tariff, the duties on rolled and hammered iron. But he seemed disinclined, and said he hoped to get rid of the new Tariff altogether.— W. Lee Ball, of Virginia, died last Night.

div.p:
2. VII—Mr Farrelly called on me this morning, again to press for the nomination of General Alden, as fourth Auditor— But most of the Pennsylvanians are for W. Findlay. Coll. R. M. Johnson came with D. Barton Senator from Missouri to recommend E. Bates as District Attorney in Missouri— I told Johnson Bates’s name was before the President— Johnson is yet speculating upon the Presidential Canvas. Clay still expects to have New-York. Govr. Barbour glories in two Letters from Connecticut to Lanman, praising his firmness, for going into Caucus— Genl. Jackson here to ask if there was a prospect of J. P. Decatur’s appointment as Consul at Tunis, and left with me
papers relating to a claim of Reuben Kemper— I attended the funeral of William Lee Ball, a member of the House of Representatives from Virginia— Mr Bascom the Methodist Chaplain of the House, read the whole Episcopal Church Service, and Dr Staughton made a prayer. On returning from the grave-yard, I stopped at the Capitol, and saw Mr.Rembrandt Peale’s Portrait of Washington— Went in to the Hall, where the seven Judges of the Supreme Court of the United States were in Session. D. Hoffman of Baltimore was speaking. I also saw and examined a new Pump, invented by Captain James Barron who was there. Walk home with Dr Thornton and went to the Office— W. C. Bradley there— Recommends S. A. Foot of Connecticut as 4th. Auditor— Says Mallary is decidedly and actively friendly to me—and that he himself was elected to Congress, for the express purpose of promoting my election— Spoke of the Report of the Committee of Elections against Bailey, and their disingenuous proceedings. E. Wyer at the Office—dejected— G. Sullivan— Advised him to make a written statement by Affidavit of W. King’s conversation with him, disclosing his design of using the Massachusetts claim as an Engine upon the Presidential Election— And to obtain a similar statement from Kidder— He proposes to do it by two or three steps— Late Dinner— Crowded Evening tea party. Miss M’Knight remains here— Mary Hellen down— A Cold.

3. VII.W. Plumer here— His conversations with Brent and Gurley of Louisiana. They both came in while he was here. Gurley to speak of Dr Floyd’s North-west Coast Bill. I advised him to see and talk with Sturgis. D. Brent here. Directions to him concerning Letters to be sent by the Peacock— Herrick of Maine—came to recommend B. Ames as Marshal, in case of vacancy, which is expected— Told me of W. King’s talk with the Judges of Common Pleas at Topsham, to persuade them to vote for M. L. Hill, Herrick’s competitor, a Crawfordite in disguise— He told them Crawford would certainly be elected: and that no person who should oppose his election would ever obtain any Office— George Blake here; for a company at New-York who have purchased Carvers claim, and wish to have an Indian Treaty held for complete acquisition of the Territory from the Indians— I referred him to the War Department— At the Office, G. Sullivan. Spoke of Mr Fitzhugh— Dined at Mr Jackson, the British Slave indemnity convention Commissioner’s. Evening at the President’s Drawing Room— Storrs, spoke of the Report against J. Bailey’s Election. Clay of his proposed Resolution concerning South-America.

4. VII. Messrs. Seymour a Senator, and Rich, a Member of the House of Representatives from Vermont were here to renew the recommendation of W. Slade jr. for fourth Auditor— They went also to the President’s— Coll. Little came also and introduced a Mr Schultz— At the Office, Mr Pedersen the Danish Minister proposed a Convention for equalizing duties between U.S. and Denmark, conformably to the Act of Congress of the present Session— The Sound duties have heretofore prevented this; but he says will not form an obstacle now— He wishes also to have the credit of concluding this negotiation himself: and said if the proposal should prove acceptable, he would write home and obtain a Power— I desired him to make it in writing— He spoke also of Mr Hughes’s projected mission to Denmark the object of which I told him— He said he expected to go next Summer to Copenhagen, on a leave of absence, during which Mr Brandis was to act as Chargé d’Affaires— Coll. R. M. Johnson and Mr D. Barton the Senator from Missouri, came again in behalf of E. Bates, whom I thought nominated as District Attorney for Missouri— Dr. Everett had told them he was not, and probably would not be, as there were objections against him— Barton enquired what they were— I had not heard of them— Barton said his character could be sustained as perfectly fair— Cazenove here; from Alexandria— Consul of the Duke of Mecklenburg—named in his Commission Charles—in the Exequatur Antoine Charles, and wanting it altered to Charles Antony— I said it must be made conformable to the Commission— At the President’s— Mentioned Pedersen’s proposal which he approves. Much perplexed about the Appointments—Of 4th. Auditor District Attorney in Missouri, and Collector at Bristol, Rhode-Island— Has received an anonymous Letter, urging the abolition of all the Auditor’s Offices but one. Mass of Congressmen at Brown’s Hotel— Popular objections to the appointment of Senators. Despatch from R. C. Anderson—Doctor Gual’s earnestness to negotiate a Treaty of Commerce there, at Bogota. Bailey at the Office— Report of Committee of Elections, in favour of J. Forsyth’s holding his Seat— Their inconsistency and disingenuousness. I advised him to go without a day’s delay, to Massachusetts, if the decision should be against him— We had company to dine— Barber, Ellis, Govan, Harvey. F. Johnson, W. R. King. M’Arthur, Mercer, Scott, Taylor of Virginia, Tracy and Van Buren. Six failed—Abbot, Cocke, Hemphill, Lathrop, G. Plumer and H. Wilson. Mrs Adams went this Evening to Pearman’s Concert. Miss Nancy Buchanan spent the last Night here, and returned this morning to Mr Frye’s.

5. VII.Coll. R. M. Johnson was here, with a Mr Morton, from Lexington Kentucky, and Mr Savage, an applicant for Office who has been twice here, in that capacity before. His recommendations are his Misfortunes— His want, a Consulate, or any profitable Office at home. At the Office I received a Note from Mr Pedersen enclosing his project of a Convention for equalizing duties between U.S. and Denmark— He came and I had some Conversation with him concerning them, as also with regard to the forms of Treaty-making— He is to call again next week. Jeremy Robinson came with Mra native of France, but who says he is a Citizen of the United States, and that he was with the Spanish Captain Martinez at the Nootka Sound Controversy with Colnett. He says he possesses sundry Surveys, Charts and Documents of that and preceding periods which he will send me from New-York. Mr. Eleazar Early likewise called on a visit— Captain Thomas Randall; for whose departure I am not prepared— Mr Lloyd N. Rogers for Letters of Introduction to Mr Rush at London, and Mr Brown at Paris: and G. Sullivan, who had received a private Letter of four lines, of 2 March from Governor Eustis—very much gratified with the Message to Congress on the Massachusetts Claim, which he had just received— The long defensive Letter of Sullivan against W. King, had not yet reached Boston. Sullivan asked again for advice as to his best course, which I freely gave him— Spent the Evening at home writing. George Johnson was here this Morning; and gave an account of the state of the Mills— They are doing nothing there. The whole Capital that I advanced for the transaction of the business has been turned into credits upon Notes in Bank, and into Shipments of Flour to Providence and Portland, with seven hundred Barrels of flour on hand unsaleable— Johnson says it was never so before—but the business was always done for cash— There is no sale for offal, and it cannot be kept. Scarcely any sale for Plaster of Paris, and little for Indian Corn Meal— The present aspect of things is disappointment and heavy loss— We agreed to wind up the concern as well as we can at the close of the first year.

6. VII.Mr T. Cooke brought a Letter from a Mr Marsham Parker proposing to take out Administration de bonis non, upon the Estate of Mr Joshua Johnson, in a County of Maryland, to pay himself a claim of five pounds and six pence for a Hogshead of Tobacco, and to recover a debt of four or five thousand dollars due from the Estate of Basil Brooke to that of Mr Johnson— We are to consult the other heirs about it. Mr Lloyd N. Rogers came to ask for the Letters that I had promised him, to R. Rush and James Brown— I told him I would send them to him at Baltimore— At the Office Mr Dodge came also to ask for the Letters I had promised him— Told him I would send them to him at New-York. Mr D. Barton came again concerning the appointment of Edward Bates as district Attorney in Missouri— G. Tomlinson to press the appointment of S. A. Foot as fourth Auditor. Tomlinson said also that he had seen a Letter from Albany, indicating the personal dispositions of every member of the Legislature, as to the Presidential Election— Dr Bates of Charleston also called, and spoke of the case of Mr Bailey— I called at the President’s: found Mr Calhoun with him, urging the appointment of B. T. Watts, as Secretary of Legation to Colombia— He soon withdrew— I spoke of the nominations. The President inclines to the suppression of the fourth Auditor’s Office— He thinks one Auditor for each Department sufficient— Spoke of 20 Members of the Pennsylvania delegation recommending W. Findlay the Senator. He told them that if nominated he would be opposed in Senate, on the principle that appointments of Senators to subaltern Executive Offices, degraded the body itself— The President said Mr R. King had declared this to be his opinion and intention— The President shewed me Lowrie’s Letter, to him informing him that he had received under a blank cover from Richmond the copy of the President’s answer to Genl. Jackson’s Letter to him recommending to him to form his Administration of the two parties— Lowrie says in his Letter he had not determined what to do— The President said, as this was a menacing attitude, he had not answered Lowrie’s Letter. Mr Baldwin afterwards had called upon him as a friend of Lowrie’s, and asked him if the affair could not be accommodated; to which he had answered there was nothing to accommodate— The President spoke also of the proposed reduction of the diplomatic appropriations, upon a Resolution offered by Forsyth, and a new Letter to me from M’Lane, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means— The President was for sustaining all the diplomatic Missions, as now authorised. I thought otherwise
but am to prepare and submit to him a draft of an answer to M’Lane’s Letter— He shewed me also a Letter from Dr. Floyd, the Chairman of the Columbia River Settlement Committee to the Secretary of War, asking for the View of the Executive on that subject in a Military point of view, and as to the controul of the Indians— He said this was going beyond the line of the Secretary of War’s duty’s. He thought therefore of sending a Message recommending the establishment of a Military post on the borders of the Pacific, and renewing the proposition for the Yellow stone river projected Post, which he said he had recommended as Secretary of War, immediately after the Peace of 1815. which Floyd and Cocke, with the help of Mr Clay had broken up; in consequence of which we had suffered Indian hostilities— These men now saw their own wrong; and were moving round and round to get themselves out of the position in which they had placed themselves— He read me an extract from his report of 1815. and said he had been much censured for assuming the responsibility of directing advances of money for the Yellow stone expedition: but he read to me an address which he had received at Lexington in July 1819. most earnestly recommending this undertaking, and signed by Isaac Shelby, General Jackson, Mr Barry of Kentucky, and several others of the first respectability. I told him that I thought the exposition of his views in the proposed Message would be entirely proper; but suggested the doubt whether connected with the enquiries of Dr Floyd to Mr Calhoun, they might not be represented as having a bearing to defeat the establishment of the Post on the Pacific— Wyer was at the Office, and said that if W. Findlay should be appointed fourth Auditor, a fac-simile of his handwriting would be published— We had company to dine. Messrs.Barker, Brandis, Crowell, Finch, Harris, R. Johnson, Keating, Lloyd, Commodore M’Donogh, Neth, Pedersen, Sergeant, Governor Stevens, and Sturgis— Blunt was here in the Evening; returned this morning from Philadelphia. Mrs Hay gave a party this Evening at the President’s House; to which the foreign Ministers were invited— A new movement which causes speculation— We were invited, but detained at home by our Company could not go. I prepared this day a draft of a Message upon the case of James Miller Governor of the Arkansas Territory, which I took to the President’s and left with him.

7. VII. Heard Dr Staughton at the Capitol. He had commenced his Sermon before I went in— The house rather thin— I called to visit Mr Webster— Not at home— Then at Claxton’s, Messrs. Reynolds, Blair and Houston of the Tennessee delegation and Irving of the Pennsylvanian— Then to see J. W. Taylor— He was not returned from Church— Then on Mr Edwards of Illinois; and found with him Mr H. S. Edwards the Senator from Connecticut, and his brother Alfred, just from New-York; who told me he was going to embark at Norfolk for Pernambuco, in Brazil. They soon left us— The nomination of N. Edwards as Minister to Mexico was confirmed in Senate last Thursday— The threatened opposition was not made, and he says there were not more than four or six votes against his appointment— He read me several Letters—one from Ogden Edwards at New-York, just received by Alfred— Confident that the vote of New-York cannot be for Crawford; and that the Electoral Bill will pass— I think the indications strongly otherwise—one from a General White in Illinois: who says D. P. Cooke wastes ammunition upon him— Edwards will resign his Seat in the Senate to-morrow; and will wait for his Instructions to go to Mexico— In the afternoon I heard Mrat Mr Baker’s, from James 3.17. “But the wisdom that is from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle, and easy to be intreated, full of mercy and good fruits, without partiality, and without hypocrisy.” an excellent practical, moral discourse. E. Wyer was here part of the Evening, and I spent the remainder of it in writing.

8. VII.Dr Thornton came in this morning, and spoke of his Memorial to Congress for an increase of his Salary— Also of the application of the Columbian Institute to Congress for an Apartment at the Capitol, and of the expected decease of Nathanael Cutting, now a Clerk in the War Department, and the wishes of his brother John Brown Cutting to obtain his place— The Doctor mentioned also the result of the Convention last Thursday at Harrisburg, Pennsylvania— Which was the nomination of Andrew Jackson by 124 votes of 125, for Election as President of the United States, and John C. Calhoun by 88 as Vice-President. Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General, came to recommend a son of Judge Burnet of Ohio, for appointment as Secretary of Legation to R. C. Anderson, Minister to the Republic of Colombia. I desired him to send a recommendation in
writing, with recommendations— M’Lean spoke to me also, of the Harrisburg nomination, and of the dispositions of the members of the present Legislature of Ohio. He said they had agreed upon two electoral tickets, one for Clay and one for me.— It was impossible to say which would prevail, but he believed Mr Clay’s prospects were waning. Clay’s only hope now is of taking all the Deserters from Crawford in New-York. M’Lean thought Calhoun would be better suited to a more active station than the Vice-Presidency— Mr Cushman called with a Mr Vose of Lancaster, Massachusetts; who has a number of sets of Wait’s State Papers to dispose of; and who afterwards called at the Office— Mr White a member of the House from Kentucky, called with an account from the Argus of Western America, Newspaper for printing. David Trimble called with Judge Trimble of the U.S. District Court in Kentucky whom he introduced— At the Office, Mr Haines of New-York came with voluminous papers, relating to a claim for damages of certain Slave traders, owners of a Vessel taken by Lieutenant Stockton, condemned by Judge Story at the Circuit Court in Boston; but restored at the motion of G. Blake, District Attorney, on a suggestion from the Executive. I told Mr Haines that if there was any remedy for the claimants, it was, by application to Congress— John Mitchell came to enquire, if I had answered the reference to me of his Petition by the Committee of Claims. I immediately took up the papers, and wrote an answer. Dined with George Sullivan— Southard, J. Sergeant, Bartlett, Rives, and a Mr Fitzhugh were there. Conversation upon State Rights, and Sovereignty— G. Sullivan read me Letters from his father and brother in Law, who as I anticipated have not published his last Letter to Governor Eustis— Sullivan talks now of going immediately to Boston, and publishing the Letter himself— I declined advising him, as to what he should do, but thought his situation required that he should defend himself against the open attack of W. King, and that the disposition of Eustis towards him was at least equivocal. He read to me also the paper he had drawn up as an affidavit of his Conversation with W. King in the Steam-Boat, in April 1823. when King told him the use that he intended to make of the Massachusetts claim, to obtain votes for Mr Crawford, at the ensuing Presidential Election. He declared himself determined at all hazards to publish his Letter to Eustis; but I think he will not.

9. VII.Mr Strong of Albany came to enquire when I should expect an answer to the enquiries I have made at his desire in Boston respecting Lieutenant Knowles: I told him certainly not before the end of next week. A. Stevenson, a member of the House from Virginia came to enquire concerning the necessity of an Agent before the Slave-indemnity Commission— I told him I thought the agency necessary. He said he thought so too— That the Committee of Ways and Means had struck out that item from the appropriation; but he should move in his place for its restoration. Mr Rufus King was here, to converse on general politics, and chiefly on the prospects of the Election. He spoke doubtfully of the dispositions of Massachusetts, Connecticut and Maine; and acknowledged that his brother W. King was the principal cause of the wavering indications in those States. He said his brother now, at New-York on his return home, had laboured without effect to bring over his two Sons, John and Charles— J. Reed Member of the House, came to speak in favour of the re-appointment of Bates as Collector of Bristol, Rhode-Island— He said all the complaints against him sprung from the vigilance with which he executed the Laws for the suppression of the Slave-trade— Coll. R. M. Johnson called for a moment, chiefly to press for the nomination of Edward Bates as District Attorney in Missouri. E. Wyer came for the pleasure of telling me something said of me by L. M’Lane— Because it was pleasant. W. Sturgis came to take leave; intending to leave the City to-morrow, on his return to Boston: and Edward Livingston for something not recollected— There was at One O’Clock a Cabinet Meeting at the President’s— Calhoun and Southard present— I was principally to read the Draft of a Message to both Houses of Congress, recommending the establishment of a military Post, high up the Missouri River; and another on the Pacific Ocean, at the Mouth of the Columbia river, or at the Straits of Juan de Fuca— But it was a strong argument against making any territorial Settlement on the Pacific, with a decided expression of an opinion that they would necessarily soon separate from this Union. I suggested doubts of the expediency or necessity of communicating such an opinion. Calhoun supported and enlarged upon my objections; and Southard concurred with us— The voice against the Message was unanimous, and the President concluded not to send it— Calhoun thought there would be no separation, should we make Settlements on the Pacific Ocean; and I inclined to the same opinion— He said the passion for aggrandizement was the Law paramount of man in Society, and that there was no example in History of the disruption of a Nation from itself—by voluntary separation. I contested
this and cited the case of the tribes of Israel. He admitted this was an exception, but said it was the only one— The position was not correct. The Separation of Portugal from Spain, and of Sweden from Denmark and Norway might have been mentioned but I did not press the discussion— We agreed in the result— I thought a Government by federation would be found practicable upon a territory as extensive as this Continent, and that the tendency of our popular sentiments was increasingly towards Union— The President spoke also respecting the appointment of a fourth Auditor. Calhoun and . . . were against the abolition of the Office— The propriety of appointing a member of Congress was discussed— I thought a member should not be appointed— Calhoun and Southard thought a Rule should be established at the commencement of an Administration, against appointing members to subaltern Offices; but now to exclude members would seem invidious— The appointment of E. Bates as District Attorney in Missouri, was also mentioned. The President fears to nominate him, Scott the Representative and Benton the Senator being violent against him— The State is distracted with parties, and there have been three or four fatal duels, arising from charges of official malversation against a General Rector, of the Land Office. Bates is one of Rectors accusers; and the President seeks some person not engaged in these controversies— He has talked with Governor M’Nair of Missouri now here: and says there is a Mr Geyer named to him as excellently well qualified, and a no party man— I said there was another view of the subject deserving Consideration— Bates had openly denounced Rector for gross official abuses— Rector instead of making a solid defence, was supported by the pistols of his friends— Was this a good objection to the appointment of Bates— Calhoun and Southard both supported my remarks, and the President said he believed the charges against Rector were well founded. He has long since been called upon for explanations and must soon give them or be dismissed— Calhoun said the propriety of appointing Bates would depend on the decision concerning Rector, and so it was left— Dined at Baron Tuyll’s with a company of about twenty— Evening party and dance at Mrs Wirts. Crowninshield said some of Calhoun’s friends were desirous that mine should vote for him as Vice-President— I asked him if Calhoun himself wished it— He did not know. I said that was first to be ascertained. I thought he did not wish it. But that some of his friends might wish mine to pledge themselves by supporting him for the Vice-Presidency, to an exterminating hostility against Crawford’s interest. I did not think this would be either just or expedient. Mr Fuller was at the Office this day after the Cabinet Meeting.

10. VII.G. Sullivan was here. He has given up his plan of going to Boston, for the present, finding that the papers relating to the claim, sent to Congress will be printed in a few days, and his presence will be necessary here—. He persists however in his determination to publish his last Letter to Governor Eustis, and says his friends have not even delivered it to the Governor— But he has sent them renewed instructions concerning it— He brought me a press copy of the Letter, which I read— I told him I thought its publication less important to him, than that Governor Eustis should explicitly approve his proceedings in the management of the claim— L. M’Lane Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means came to make enquiries respecting several items in the general Appropriation Bill, now before the House of Representatives. Mr Bradley of Vermont came for the same object— Mr George Hay, with a Slave average value document— Mr Conway the Delegate from the Arkansas Territory came and introduced the Governor of the State of Missouri, M’Nair— Mr Burton, member from North-Carolina introduced a Mr Wyche, from that State— At the Office, I wrote to Mr M’Lane, the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, answers to two Letters received from him— The Count de Menou, Charge d’Affaires from France, came, to speak of the publication of a notice that Certificates of Origin would be required in France, upon importations from the United States to entitle them to the benefit of the Convention— We conversed also upon general topics, and I spoke to him of the newspaper accounts of a large Squadron fitting out at Brest— He said he had no doubt there was exaggeration in the accounts— That a squadron of three frigates in the Pacific, had returned to France, and were to be replaced—that the Garrisons of the French Islands in the West-Indies were perhaps to be relieved, and that the French Government might be disposed to contribute its share to the suppression of Piracy in those Seas— I told him I discredited altogether the suspicions abroad that this squadron was destined to act against any part of South-America, particularly as I knew there had been explanations upon the subject which had passed between the British and French Governments; and as related to South-America, I presumed that no interposition of France between them and Spain would take place without consulting the United States, as well as her European Allies— This appeared to startle him a little, and he said he did not see that France was bound to consult the United States as to the time when she should recognize the South-American Governments— I said by no means— It was not, when she should recognize them, but whether she should interfere between them and Spain, to which my observation applied— He did not pursue the subject further.
I spent the Evening at home— Joseph Blunt, D. P. Cook and G. Sullivan were here successively, and absorbed all my time.

11. VII.Govr Branch a Senator, and Mr Mangum a member of the House from North-Carolina came to recommend a Mr Mann of that State, for the appointment of Secretary of Legation to the Republic of Colombia. Mr. Benjamin Ames of Maine, brought me Letters of recommendation from J. Wingate jr. of Portland and Jos. T. Wingate of Bath, for the appointment of U.S. Marshal in Maine vacant by the Death of Thornton. Chief Justice Marshall called for a visit, just recovering from his accident, and with his arm yet in a Sling— J. Bailey was here— Concerned about the Report of the Committee of Elections against him which has not yet been taken up in the house— His health is very bad, and he has a severe cough upon him— Mr Cushman and Mr Burleigh came with recommendations from members of the Senate of Maine, of B. Green, Speaker of their House of Representatives, for the appointment of Marshal— Green himself will be here in a few days. I told them I thought they were too late— Mr Fuller called and I had a long Conversation with him upon the Massachusetts claim, and upon a motion of J. Forsyth’s for reducing the sum estimated in the appropriation Bill now before the House of Representatives, for the diplomatic intercourse— He began with a general assault upon the whole estimate, proposing a discontinuance of the Plenipotentiary Missions in Spain and Portugal, as well as all those in South-America— But failing in this he has finished by proposing to strike out the item of Salary for a Minister to Lima. This may be spared without inconvenience, and I do not regret the appearance of this disposition in the house— At the Office— Mr Cathcart came with a renewal of his inextinguishable claims— Congress have given him more than ten thousand Dollars within these four years, but he wants more. Mr Southard, Secretary of the Navy, came to ask for a Letter from Commodore Stewart, which he had sent me, and which I had just sent back to the Navy Department— Southard talked with me largely upon Election Prospects, and was apparently desirous of ascertaining my Sentiments concerning Calhoun, and Jackson—. I gave them to him without reserve— The Pennsylvania Convention at Harrisburg have nominated Jackson for President and Calhoun Vice-President. Southard thought the Vice-Presidency was not the place for Calhoun, but yet seemed inclined that he should be voted for to it— He asked who my friends
would vote for— I told him, probably Jackson— He asked if that would not strengthen Jackson’s chance of success for the Presidency. I had no doubt it would— But what then?— My friends would vote for him on correct principle— His fitness for the place— The fitness of the place for him, and the peculiar advantage of the geographical association— If by voting for him as Vice-President my friends should induce others to vote for him as President, they and I must abide by the issue. It is upon the whole the best course to be taken; and besides the impulse to that course in the popular feeling is given. It is too late to withstand or to controul it— Southard said he had seen a member of the Harrisburg Convention; who had given him a very detailed account of their proceedings— That the presence of H. Baldwin, though not a member, and considered as a Crawfordite under a Jackson mask, had occasioned much agitation— And that multitudes of Letters had been received from this place reporting a Coalition between Crawford and me— The person to whom Southard alluded, though he did not name him to me was Mr M’Ilvaine, a Son of the Senator from N. Jersey. We had company to dinner. Messrs. P. P. Barbour, H. G. Burton, John FindlayJames L. Hogeboom, Stephen Longfellow, Thomas Metcalfe, Gabriel Moore, John F. Parrott, John Reed, John Sloane, Ansel Sterling, James Strong, Philip Thompson— David Trimble, and Judge Robert Trimble, Joseph Vance, Thomas Whipple, James Wilson and Mr Wyche— Adam R. Alexander of Tennessee, John Elliott of Georgia, and Waller Taylor of Indiana, were invited, but sent excuses— Evening visits from George Sullivan, and J. Knap of Boston— Sullivan had sent me this morning a Letter that he had received from Governor Eustis, expressing in the fullest and most unequivocal manner his approbation of Sullivan’s conduct in the management of the claim— I now told him that it was comparatively of little importance that his last Letter to Eustis should be published, but he said he was determined to publish it. That he had written repeatedly to his father in Law, to urge upon Eustis the necessity that he should publish it; and if he should decline, it should still be published—of this I am yet a little incredulous; and I told Sullivan that under present circumstances, I wished him to understand that I did not advise its publication. I said this, because W. King having made this Claim and all his conduct relating to it an electioneering Engine against me, I should distrust my own judgment in advising the publication which would expose King, as possibly biassed, by my own apparent interest— I believe the publication, or at least the disclosure of W. King’s projects necessary to Sullivan for his justification before the People of Maine and Massachusetts, to whom King has openly denounced him; but this is for Sullivan to see with his own eyes, and not by advice from me; and if he from prudential considerations applicable to himself, or to the benefit of the claim, refrains from the publication, it is not for me to urge it upon him.

12. VII.Dr Thornton and Keller came to me this morning, anxious to know what I had done with Keller’s petition for employment at the Patent Office. I had sent it to Mr M’Lane, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means— Received a Note from the President, requesting the attendance of Mr Calhoun,Mr Southard and me at his house, at ten O’Clock this Morning. We met there accordingly— The first subject of consultation was a Letter from M’Lane Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means to Mr Crawford, enquiring, whether in consequence of the decease of the fourth Auditor, any Appropriation for the Salary of that Officer would be necessary, and how the Appropriations of the year would be affected by that Event— Mr Crawford who is yet unwell tho’ convalescent had endorsed a reference of this Letter to the President, remarking that if the Office should be abolished, as the President had inclined to the opinion that it might the Appropriation for the Salary would be unnecessary— Calhoun and Southard now thought that the Office could not be abolished, without doubling the labours of the third Auditor Peter Hagner, already overlaboured— It was proposed to call upon him to say whether he could do the additional duties of the fourth Auditor, but I suggested that to require of him a formal Report upon that question, would be placing him in a delicate and awkward position, which considering him as a most excellent Officer would be hardly dealing fairly with him. I proposed that Mr Crawford should answer Mr M’Lane’s Letter, by observing that the question upon the expediency of abolishing the Office, would require time and deliberation to decide; and that in the mean time if the appropriation should be made, it would remain unexpended in case the result of the examination should be to abolish the Office— It was determined accordingly— The next subject submitted for consideration by the President was more important— By a compact made between the U. States, and the State of Georgia in 1802. the United States stipulated to extinguish as soon as should be practicable peaceably and upon reasonable terms the Indian titles to lands within the State of Georgia— And since that time many Treaties have been made and many Millions of miles purchased in fulfilment of the Article— The State of Georgia continually pressing to obtain more. At last the Cherokees have come to the determination that they will on no consideration part with any more of their Lands, and their delegation now here have most explicitly so declared; in answer to a Letter from the Secretary of War, strongly urging upon
them the necessity of a further cession. The answer of the Cherokees was communicated to the Georgia delegation here; and they have addressed to the President a Letter of remarks upon the correspondence between the Secretary of War and the Cherokees, which the President said was an insult. It is in terms of the most acrimonious reproach against the Government of the United States, whom it charges almost in terms, with fraud and hypocrisy, while it broadly insinuates, that the obstinacy of the Cherokees, is instigated by the Secretary of War himself— Calhoun remarked that it was in the hand-writing of Cobb, but it was signed by the two Senators Elliott and Ware, and by all the members of the house from the State, excepting Tattnall who is not here. The question was how it should be treated— The conclusion was that the President should send a Message to Congress, with the Correspondence, and an exposition of what has been done by the Government of the United States in fulfilment of the compact— Calhoun thought that the message should communicate, but take no notice of the Letter of the Georgia delegation— I said as the charges of the Letter could not be overlooked, it was scarcely possible to avoid a direct allusion to it; and I thought it indispensable, that it should in substance be fully answered. The President said it should be answered, and in the tone of defiance best suited to it. Southard said Georgia would find very little support in Congress to such a paper as that. The President said he had never received such a paper— I said it was an issue tendered between Georgia and the Government of the United States— Calhoun dwelt upon its incorrectness with regard to the facts, and I observed it was a peremptory demand to do by force, and upon most unreasonable terms, that which had been stipulated only to be done peaceably, and upon reasonable terms— It was asked what could have kindled this raging fever for Indian Lands— Calhoun thought it was the State system of disposing of them by Lottery— A system which he said was immoral and corrupt. Instigating insatiable cupidity, for Lands; and alternately seized by the conflicting parties as Engines for the advancement of one upon the ruin of the other. I suspected this bursting forth of Georgia upon the Government of the United States was ominous of other Events— We were kept till past 3. at the Presidents. At the Office Captain M’Donogh came, with his demand for furnishing Cabin Stores for G. W. Campbell and his family, when they went with him in the Frigate Guerriere to Russia— They cost 2000 dollars— Campbell at first would have paid only 400. but finally paid 800. M’Donogh, considered 600, as being a large proportion for himself, and made out an account for 600 against the United States— I had laid this account before the President, but there was no fund from which it could be paid. It could therefore not be allowed.
There was a Ball this Evening at Coll. Henderson’s which John and Abigail Adams attended. Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen were indisposed and did not go. They had attended this morning the funeral of Commodore Chauncey’s daughter who died after a short illness the day before yesterday— I passed the Evening at home, and answered a Letter received this morning from James Tallmadge at Albany. I received also despatches from R. Rush and two eccentric Letters from J. A. Smith.

13. VII.Mr A. B. Woodward late Chief Justice of the Territory of Michigan came and left with me a number of documents in justification of his character— The representations and remonstrances against him were so strong and numerous that the President left him out of the nomination for re-appointment and another was appointed in his place. The principal charge against him was of intemperance— His documents now are strong and respectable contesting the fact— Genl. M’Kean, member of the house from Pennsylvania came and introduced a Mr Robertson from that State— Card left by a Mr Parker of Cincinnati, Ohio. Mr Vose was here about his project for publishing the State Papers during the present Administration— Mr Heman Lincoln brought me Letters of recommendation from S. Parkman and Josiah Quincy of Boston. He comes upon a contest for a road from Boston to Watertown, between the West-Boston Bridge and the Mill Corporations— There is a permission from the War Department to the Mill Corporation, to carry the road through the U.S. Arsenal Land. The Bridge proprietors wish to carry the road in another direction and ask the Secretary of War to withdraw the permission already granted— This he declines, and they question the legality of his permission— I thought it legal, and that it could not be withdrawn, without the consent of the Mill Corporation— Lincoln talked of an application to Congress. Mr D. Brent called to speak concerning the settlement of some contingent expenses of the Office. Strong of Albany came with the papers relating to his petition, to Congress, against which the Committee have reported. He had also much to say of a secret design, which he suspected Mr Van Buren to entertain, to bring in De Witt Clinton as President. Mr Bailey was here, still much out of health, and with the Report of the Committee of Elections against him not taken up by the House. At the Office, Mr R. King came with Mr Wheaton, who is a member of the New-York Legislature, and will leave the City next Tuesday, to return to Albany. Wheaton wished to converse with me concerning
the Presidential Election— His great apprehension appeared to be the rumoured Coalition between Crawford and myself— I told him what had passed in relation to this subject— The overtures from some of Mr Crawford’s friends, and the answers given by me to them; with which he expressed himself fully satisfied. I mentioned to him the Letter that I had received from Mr Tallmadge and told him the substance of my Answer— After he withdrew I had further Conversation with Mr King, concerning the commercial intercourse with the British West-India Colonies—the Affair between the President and W. Lowrie the Senator from Pennsylvania, and the Letter to the President from the Georgia delegation— Upon all which I found his opinions concurring with my own— Mr Addington the British and the Count de Menou the French Charge d’Affaires successively came; apparently to obtain information concerning the recent intelligence from Europe— There are despatches and Letters from London, to the 17th. of February, a vessel having arrived in 16 days from Liverpool at Boston— I spoke to Addington of a notice from the British Vice-Consulate at Portland concerning an Act of the Legislature of the Island of Jamaica, published in the Newspapers, and told him I should write him a note to enquire if it was authentic— He said he did not know— I observed that we should have occasion to animadvert upon it in two points of view— First as an Official act of a British Consulate in the United States, relating to their commercial intercourse with the Island of Jamaica, while no consul from the United States was allowed to reside in that Island, and secondly as laying our shipping and Merchants trading there under additional duties and burdens. Addington spoke also to me again upon the affair of the duties on rolled and hammered iron— Mr Hatch of Attleborough came likewise to the Office; here for Post-Office Contracts— He was with me till past six, while I was opening Letters and despatches, from Spain, England, Denmark and Mexico— I intended to have written all the Evening; but Mr Crowninshield, G. Sullivan and Blunt came in successively and kept me engaged till near Midnight.

div.p:
14. VII.Dr Thornton came in to inform me of the discomfiture of poor Keller, upon the failure of his petition to Congress, and also that a Subcommittee of the Senate upon his own Memorial for an increase of Salary, had been to visit the Patent Office, and one of the members, Holmes of Maine was disposed to find fault with every thing— The Doctor went with me to Mr Little’s where we heard a Mr Green, from 1. John 3.2. “Beloved, now are we the sons of God, and it doth not yet appear what we shall be: but we know that when he shall appear we shall be like him; for we shall see him as he is.” I could make out neither doctrine, nor precept from this discourse, which was yet written in a pure tho’ colourless style— I called at Mr N. Edwards’s lodgings to see him, but he was gone to Georgetown. I found and paid a short visit to Mr Noble, the Senator from
Indiana— Then came home and received a heavy Mail of Letters and despatches— Mr Rosenkrantz, the Minister of Foreign Affairs in Denmark, is dead, and Count Blome, Danish Minister at St. Petersburg is to take his place— The Baron de Nagel, Minister of Foreign Affairs to the King of the Netherlands has resigned, and Baron Henry Fagel the ambassador at London, takes his place— And the Marquis of Casa-Yrujo Minister of foreign Affairs in Spain is also dead— These changes will produce some, but not much effect on the Affairs of Europe— This Afternoon at Mr Baker’s I heard a Mr Russell from Isaiah 40.1. “Comfort ye, comfort ye my people, saith your God.” The very sound of that sublime text, is refreshing, and this preacher spoke the words with proper emphasis— His powers of Oratory were considerable, but nothing memorable remains upon my mind from his Sermon— In the Evening Mr John W. Taylor, the member from the State of New-York called on me, and we were in conversation of interest when Dr Lovell came in to enquire if Mr John M. Forbes was at Buenos-Ayres— Taylor mentioned to me the postponement by the Senate of New-York, to the 1st. of November next, or in other words the rejection of the Bill which had passed the House of Assembly, for giving the choice of the Electors of President and Vice-President of the United States, for that State, to the People— Taylor says that Van Buren announces that the next step will be the confirmation by a Legislative Caucus of the Congressional Caucus-nomination; but Taylor’s own Letters from Albany all say, that there is not a majority of the Legislature in favour of Crawford. Van Buren’s information is probably the most correct, and I now set down the New-York votes as nearly certain for Crawford. The Union of New-York and Virginia will thus be consummated under inauspicious omens, a minority Caucus in Congress, and an antipopular Legislative usurpation in the State of New-York— And after all it is insufficient to make the final Election of Crawford ever probable.

15. VII.Mr Vose called again at my house, upon his project for publishing the State-Papers, during the Administration of Mr Monroe— I indicated to him from my own Collection many of those which would properly come within his plan; but he found them so numerous that he was afraid the list would alarm the Committee to whom his memorial has been referred— Strother the late keeper of the Hotel in the neighbourhood of my house to ask my opinion of the present value of it; but I was not able to answer him at this time. E. A. Brown came and introduced a Mr. Hunt from Cincinnati, in the State of Ohio. Mr Burleigh and Mr Cushman of
Maine came with Mr Benjamin Green, who is a Candidate for the appointment of Marshal for the District of Maine— Mr Green is Speaker of the House of Representatives of that State, but his application is too late; his competitor Benjamin Ames having been nearly a week here. Judge Cranch of Alexandria, gave a morning call— At the Office Ninian Edwards, the newly appointed Minister to Mexico came to enquire when I should be ready to despatch him— I said immediately— He proposes to go first home to Illinois; thence down the Mississippi to New-Orleans; and there embark for Vera-Cruz or Alvarado. I told him I could prepare his Instructions and send them by his Secretary John Mason to New-Orleans— I had a long conversation with him, upon the personal concerns of the Mission. Mr Herrick a member of the House from Maine, came with a recommendation of Mr Green, as Marshal. I called at the President’s with the despatches last received from H. Nelson, and from R. Rush— The President told me that last Saturday, Mr Crawford had called at his house— That he had appeared to be much mortified at the Letter from the Georgia delegation, which the President had shewn him; and had expressed a wish that they might be induced to withdraw it— That the President told him they might withdraw it if they pleased; but it must be their own act, and not at his desire— He gave me also to read a Letter from the Governor of Georgia to the Secretary at War, upon the same subject, which he said though in some respects exceptionable was in a different Spirit, from the Delegation Letter, and contained a refutation of their insinuations of duplicity on the part of the General Government— I dined at General Jackson’s, with a company of about 25. Heads of Departments, Members of Congress, and Officers of the Army and Navy— Clay and Calhoun were there;— It was the General’s birth-day, and apparently the occasion upon which he gave the dinner— Clay had been arguing in the Supreme Court this morning, the case of the Apollon, against the Government, and had taken the opportunity of being as he professed very severe upon me— At the dinner he became warm, vehement, and absurd upon the tariff, and persisted in discussing it, against two or three attempts of Eaton to change the subject of the Conversation— He is so ardent, dogmatical and overbearing that it is extremely difficult to preserve the temper of friendly society with him. I had some conversation with Mr Southard who sat next me at table, on the Georgia Delegation Letter, which he thought would not be taken back— I thought it would—at the intercession of Mr Crawford; and had a suspicion that it was written and sent with that intention. Southard said this was to him a new view of the subject— Attended a large Evening dancing party at Mr T. Munro’s. Mary Hellen and John, there. Mrs Adams and Abigail, unwell and could not go. The President asked me to attend at his house at 11 to-morrow Morning.

16. VII. I called this morning on T. Newton, Chairman of the Committee of Commerce. Mr S. Breck a Member of the House from Pennsylvania offered a Resolution, founded upon Newspaper Reports of proceedings in the British Parliament, relating to our commercial intercourse with the British West-India Colonies— Newton opposed the Resolution, which was of a reference to the Committee of Commerce of which he is chairman— I told him I wished him to let the Resolution to pass, and send me a copy of it asking for my observations upon it, as it would give me an opportunity for making a communication to the Committee, and through them to Congress, which I was desirous of doing— He said he would assent to the passage of the Resolution— On returning home, Mr Green came, and Mr Cushman soon afterwards— Green was stating to me the grounds of his expectation of receiving the appointment of Marshal in Maine— I was obliged to inform him that his application was too late; the nomination of Mr Ames, having been made out before he arrived; and intended to have been sent to the Senate last Friday— This interview detained me until I received a message from the President to go to his House; and arriving there I found General Jackson, reading his answer to an Address, which the President had read to him, on presenting him the medal voted by a Resolution of Congress of 27. February 1815. for the victory of 8. January at New-Orleans— Immediately afterwards the President read an Address to Judge Todd as the Representative of Governor Isaac Shelby, on delivering him a Medal voted by Resolution of Congress, of 4 April 1818. for his good conduct at the battle of the Thames on the 5th. of October 1813— The Judge read an answer to the President’s Address— The whole ceremony was over in a quarter of an hour or less, and there were not more than thirty persons present, among whom were the Ladies of the President’s family. Mr Poinsett spoke to me of Breck’s Resolution, and I gave him as I had given to Mr Newton, my reasons for wishing that it might pass— After I returned to the Office, Mr Mallary of Vermont came and introduced to me a Mr Post, now of the State of Missouri, but formerly of Massachusetts. Mr Palacio the Consul General from the Republic of Colombia came to take leave; going in two days to Philadelphia— Mr Savage came to make enquiries of his prospect of obtaining a Consular Appointment— In the Evening we had the usual alternate Tuesday evening dancing party. The weather was bad, and the company less numerous than common, about one hundred, among whom 9 Senators and twenty members of the House of Representatives. Mr M’Ilvaine S.U.S. from New-Jersey was
at the office this morning to recommend a person for the appointment of keeper of the Light-house at Sandy Hook: I referred him to the Treasury Department under the superintendence of which the whole Light-house establishment is placed. Mr M’Ilvaine spoke also much of the Presidential Election, and the dispositions of the State of New-Jersey.

17. VII. Visit from James Miller, Governor of the Arkansas Territory. He has been absent upon leave at his home in New-Hampshire, these eight or nine Months on account of his Health. His Constitution appears to have been destroyed by the climate of that Country; and after making an attempt to return thither last October he was detained by relapses of disease until this time— He is now convalescent, but yet quite infirm; and desirous if possible to obtain some place in exchange for that which he now holds, and which will allow him to reside in his native climate— He spoke of the Post-Office, or the Navy-Agency at Boston. Coll. Richard M. Johnson came and introduced a Coll. Croghan, and also a Mr Greer of Baltimore, who said he would call upon me on business at the Office— John M’Kee a member of the House from Alabama, brought an account of T. Easton, printer of the Halcyon Newspaper for publishing the Laws of the last Session of Congress— He had also the Circular Letter of Appointment issued 6. December 1822. authorizing him to print the Laws of that Session, at St. Stephens— He had then however removed from St. Stephens to Greensborough, and suspended the publication of his paper— On the 1st. of March last year W. R. King one of the Senators from Alabama came, and representing that the Halcyon had been drop’d, recommended the appointment of the Mobile Argus in its stead— It was appointed accordingly. The Laws of the Session were printed in it, for which its printers have been paid— In the meantime Easton recommenced his Halcyon at Greensborough, printed the Laws in it there under the Letter issued for printing them at St. Stephens, and now claims payment of his printing account— I told Mr M’Kee this was not possible— The Law permitting me to print the Laws only in three Newspapers in each State, and that number having already been paid for in Alabama— I shall write to him. Mr George Sullivan came and shewed me a Letter which he proposed sending to his brother in Law, Winthrop, urging the publication of his late Letter to Governor Eustis; by a long argument, concerning which he asked my advice. I asked the motive for writing it— He said, that it might be read to Eustis— I said there were three points upon which the exposure of W. King’s designs would bear— 1. On Sullivan’s defence against King’s public denunciation— 2. On the prospects of the Claim. 3. On the Presidential Election. For the first I believed it necessary for Sullivan’s full justification. As to the second I was
altogether doubtful, whether its operation upon the claim would be favourable or adverse— And could not advise as to the third—I had no doubt the effect would be favourable to me, but must set that consideration aside, and distrust my own judgment lest it should be improperly biassed by my own interest— Sullivan thought the effect must be favourable to the claim; by exasperating all Crawford’s friends against it, and thereby writing the friends of all the other Candidates in its support— I said I believed Governor Eustis for various reasons would be strenuously against the publication, and I advised Sullivan to give full consideration to the arguments he would urge against it— Sullivan said he intended to go into the House of Representatives of Massachusetts this year, and thought he should make a very good Speaker— And in the House he would take care that full Justice should be done to himself— I attended this Evening alone the Drawing-Room at the President’s. Less company than usual. Bad weather. Heard of Mr Wirt’s reply this day before the Supreme Court to Clay’s attack upon the Administration and upon me, on Monday, in the case of the Apollon. G. Hay was in raptures at the scourging Clay received. Clay spoke of it to me himself; but in a very humble tone compared with that of Monday— Clay said he had wanted a half an hour for reply. I said he should have thought of that when he attacked me where he knew I could not reply— He said Wirt had made my Letter to De Neuville a part of his argument— I hold him he had fine scope for assailing me where I was not present to defend myself; but in this instance I had been gratified to learn that my defence had fallen into better hands than my own. Bradley spoke to me of the proceedings of the House this day in J. Bailey’s case— The Committee of the whole adopted the Report of the Committee of Elections against him by a majority of about two to one. John went this Evening to the theatre— Mrs Adams and the girls were not well enough to go out— Abigail yet keeps her chamber—

18. VII.Mr Greer of Baltimore called at the Office, to make application for an appointment in any of the public Offices in the Departments. He had a strong recommendation from several persons of highly respectable character, among-whom was Charles Carroll of Carrollton. It was addressed to the Treasury Department, and he left a written application with a reference to it with me— Mr Edmund J. Lee of Alexandria came to make enquiry, in behalf of Ambrose Vasse, on a Claim for interest payable from the fund of the old Commission of Claims between the United States and Great-Britain in 1796— Mr Delafield the Agent to the Commission upon the 6th. and 7th Articles of the Treaty of
Ghent, brought me a Report of the proceedings of the Commission at a meeting recently held by them at Albany— Delafield shewed me also a draught of the Lake of the Woods, by the surveys of the last Summer, and spoke of General Porter’s political concerns at Albany— G. Sullivan came to speak in behalf of B. Green, the disappointed candidate for the appointment of Marshal in Maine— He wished me to see Green again, and hear him upon his claims, pretensions and expectations— I said I would be glad to see him; but that to hear him again would be useless; having already heard all that he could say on this topic— I began the answer to a Letter received last Evening from S. Smith, Chairman of the Committee of Finance of the Senate, containing sundry questions upon the Appropriation Bill— We had company to dine with us— Messrs.S. C. Allen, Craig, Condict, Delafield, Jenkins, Kelly, Macon, T. P. Moore, Ross, Standefer, Stevenson, and one other member whose name I did not ascertain— Nine other members invited, did not come, of whom four sent excuses, three never answered the invitations and two had accepted, but neither sent excuses nor came— After the company were gone, I went to the Theatre and saw the after-piece of Catherine and Petruchio, indifferently performed— There were this day warm debates in both Houses of Congress this day— The Resolution against J. Bailey was carried by yeas and nays 125 to 55. A Resolution offered by M’Duffie in which the only real principle involved in the case was set forth, was precluded from discussion, by the previous question—and M’Duffie declined voting, therefore on the main question— In the Senate the proposed amendments to the Constitution, respecting the Election of President and Vice-President were debated, and some sharp personalities were said to have passed between some of the Members—R. King—Holmes of Maine, and Noble— Stevenson said he expected the Tariff would bring up new heats, but I believe that diversity of interest will be controuled by others, and thereby much neutralized— The gall of bitterness will flow if at all, from other fountains.

19. VII.Mr George Hay came this morning and brought me a Letter and statement respecting the average value of Slaves in 1815. as evidence to be laid before the Commissioners if I thought proper, considering his Agency to be at an end— The House of Representatives persisted in reducing the appropriation for the expences of that Commission, so as to strike out the Salary of the Agent— Hay says there will be an effort to restore it in the Senate, but that he does not expect it will prevail; and cares nothing about it—for it will quite suit his views to have a good deal of leisure the ensuing Summer— W. Plumer was here, and spoke of the decision of the House yesterday against the Election of J. Bailey.
It was the triumph of prejudice over principle; and the list of yeas and nays shews with a very few exceptions that the vote against Bailey was implicated with invidious personalities— There were about thirty members who did not vote— Coll. R. M. Johnson of the Senate was here; soliciting a consular appointment for Mr Savage at Guayaquil. I advised him rather to think of the Island of St. Bartholomew. Johnson says Mr Crawford’s friends, particularly Governor Barbour are very sangwine of his Election, and entirely sure of the vote of New-York. They consider all prospect of my being supported as having vanished; and that all New-England will abandon me and vote for Crawford— I believe Mr Crawford’s prospects and mine equally unpromising. Intrigue, against the voice of the People will probably give him New-York— Virginia, Georgia, North-Carolina and Delaware, will also probably be for him; but no others, and if New-York fails him, he will decline and withdraw. Whether all New-England will support me is yet problematical, and the rest is yet more uncertain— The issue must be where it ought to be, and my duty is cheerful acquiescence in the Event— Morning visit from T. H. Benton, Senator from Missouri, just recovered from a dangerous illness— At the Office, Dr. Sewall came with a book for Dr. Cony, and to recommend a person named Fondé, for a Clerkship or employment in the Department. A Son of the late James A. Bayard came to the Office for two objects. First as an Executor, jointly with L. M’Lane, of his father’s Will—to claim a half-outfit for the negotiation of the Convention of July 1815. because Mr Bayard was joined in the Commission for that Negotiation; though he did not go to London upon it— His accounts have been long since settled; but he takes ground from the allowances to Mr Clay and Mr Gallatin; and says Mr Clay encourages him to make the claim, and Mr M’Lane considers it as a vested right— I told him if he should make the claim, I should refer it to the President, who had made the allowance to Mr Clay, after taking the opinion of the Attorney General, and against mine— He thought he must make the claim— His second purpose was to solicit the appointment of Secretary of Legation to France, in the event of D. Sheldon’s return home, this year; which he said was expected— I had no reason for such expectation, but promised to befriend him if Sheldon should return. I received a Note from the President asking me to return the Letter from Governor Troup of Georgia, to the Secretary of War, which he had given me some days ago— I took the Letter over to the President’s House, and he being out, left it upon his table— He came afterwards to the Office, and spoke of the joint-Letter
from the Georgia Delegation to him. He said that Mr Crawford in pursuance of the desire expressed by himself that they should withdraw the paper, had seen Mr Elliott the Senator— And he had consulted with the rest of the Delegation; who thereupon determined not to withdraw the paper; nor to hold any consultation with Mr Crawford concerning it— Governor Barbour of Virginia told the President that the paper was written by Forsyth and copied by Cobb. The President is deeply affected by it. He thinks it proceeds from Forsyth and Cobb’s eagerness for popularity in Georgia stimulated by the passion of the People for lands which are distributed among them by Lottery under the State Laws; and by party ambition to outdo the Clarke faction in the State— He said there were three courses, either of which he might pursue with regard to the paper, one to send it back to the writers— Another to keep it without answering it. The third to send it to Congress— Of these, the last was the most advisable— I suggested to him the expediency of referring the paper to the Secretary of War for a Report, in this the errors both of fact and of principle might be fully exposed; and then both papers might be sent, by Message to Congress together— And I reminded him that this was the course adopted when R. W. Meade memorialized him against the second Ratification of the Florida Treaty. He said he thought he would take this course— I spent the Evening with a small party at G. Sullivan’s. Chess with Dr Tucker. Music by Miss Wirt and Miss Davis— I sat an hour with Sullivan after all the rest of his company were gone. Abigail S. Adams came down stairs, convalescent.

20. VII.Mr N. Edwards the newly appointed Minister to Mexico, called this morning, and made enquiries of the manner in which it will be most expedient for him to proceed upon his Mission— It is most advisable for him to proceed hence to New Orleans, and there embark, to land with in a few Miles of Vera-Cruz— He also gave me an explanatory account of his own, conduct personally towards me for the last three years— It was apologetic, And excusatory— He had begun by volunteering as my friend, and then by his own account abandoned me for Calhoun, because he thought there was no possible chance in my favour, and because his great object paramount to all others was to put down Crawford— I told him with candour all that had rested upon my mind, in the variations of his dispositions and conduct towards me; assuring him that I retained no sentiment of animosity for it— He declared to me his conviction that it was the attack of Jonathan Russell upon me, and its consequences which had brought me up as a candidate for the Presidency— But for that, he is persuaded I should have been out of the question— He says also that the Winter before that occurrence, when he and Clay boarded at Mrs Peyton’s, Clay intimated to him that he intended to operate against me with that Mississippi
and fishery dispute; and he has no doubt it was then that Clay stimulated Floyd, who also then lodged at Mrs Peyton’s, to his movements of the succeeding Winter— He says nothing that Clay ever did in the whole course of his life, has hurt his character so much as his Parthian shaft at me and his subsequent flinching from the contest that he had challenged. General Macomb called upon me and introduced GeneralMr Raymond of Baltimore brought a written recommendation of a namesake and kinsman of his for an appointment as a Receiver of Public Monies in the Western Country— Mr Maxcy of Maryland, and Mr Fuller called, but I did not see them— At the Office, Mr Bailey called for a moment, but I was engaged with Mr R. King, who came and mentioned to me the debate which has been the last two days in discussion before the Senate— He told me the substance of his remarks on the central power, which by the combination of certain individual members from two of the Great States was establishing itself here at Washington to controul the Constitution itself— I suggested to him the wish that he would reduce to writing the purport of his observations, and publish them; to which he appeared disposed to assent— We spoke also of the approaching controversy between the Georgia Delegation, and the Executive Government of the United States— I told him the course that I had recommended to the President concerning it—he thought it the best that could be taken. Mr Edwards called again at the Office to be despatched; intending to go off on Monday— But must wait one day longer— Mr Nelson, a member from Massachusetts came to make enquiries concerning sundry claims— I finished the answer to S. Smith, Chairman of the Committee of Finance of the Senate, concerning the Appropriations— I called also at the Bank of the Metropolis; and had an unpleasant explanation with A. Kerr; concerning a note of Mrs Mary G. Moulton, endorsed by me. My endorsement was obtained by misrepresentations, and the note itself as given by a married woman is void, and not recoverable by me. Kerr has transferred the Note to the President and Directors of the Bank of the Metropolis, who have protested it, and caused notice to be given to me of the protest— I charged Kerr with the unfairness of his conduct, but offered to pay part of the Note, leaving him to his remedy against Mrs Moulton for the remainder— He refused this as an unreasonable proposal, but offered a reference to impartial persons— This I accepted, but he then said the thing must take its regular course— I endorsed the note, to save the woman and her infant children from perishing, under a distress by Kerr, for Rent; and without due consideration I took the
woman’s Note, and endorsed it; not reflecting that it was void; and therefore not recoverable by me from her even if I should pay it— I am willing to pay smart money for my endorsement; but not to submit to the imposition of Kerr— I went this Evening to the Theatre, and saw the Stranger, and Of Age tomorrow— The Company are inferior performers to those of our Summer Theatre— The House was thin— Met Mr Southard there, and several Members of Congress— Mrs Adams was confined all day to her bed, with a fresh attack of Erysipelas.

21. VII.Dr Thornton came in this Morning; desponding under the unfavourable dispositions of the Committee of Finance of the Senate, towards his application, owing to the Vandalism of Mr Holmes of Maine. But he is to attend the Committee to-morrow, and asked me to attend them also, which I declined, unless they should request my attendance— Mr G. Hay was here, and enquired whether it would not be expedient for the Executive when notifying to the claimants under the Slave-indemnity Commission, to advise the claimants upon the discontinuance of the Public Agency, to appoint a general Agent themselves—though he said he would not accept the Agency. I thought the notification of discontinuance would be all that would be proper. Heard a Stranger at Mr Baker’s this morning, from Revelations 3.4. “Thou hast a few names even in Sardis which have not defiled their Garments; and they shall walk with me in white: for they are worthy.” The character of the Sermon did not correspond with the singularity of the text. In the afternoon, Mr Russell of Norfolk preached from Philippians 2.21. “For all seek their own, not the things which are Jesus Christ’s.” And a collection was taken for the support of the Sunday School of the Congregation. Mr Russell was more vehement, but less eloquent than he had been last Sunday— I called at the beginning of the Evening, upon Coll. John Taylor the Senator from Virginia; and R. S. Garnett the member of the House who has just returned from a visit home— Taylor continues low in health and feeble— He repeated to me the anecdote concerning Patrick Henry, which he had related some weeks since at my house— That in the campaign of 1781—Henry actually proposed in a secret Session of the Legislature of Virginia, that she should be the first to submit to Great Britain, in order that she might obtain the most favourable terms. Taylor was himself a member of the Legislature and heard him move to go in to secret Session; there make the proposition and support it by an eloquent speech— It met with such immediate, indignant and universal opposition, that when the debate closed, he had changed his side, and was among the most ardent and sangwine for perseverance in the War— Taylor thinks there is great exaggeration, in the panegyric upon Henry—by Mr Wirt, and says that Henry had
much less efficient agency in the Revolution than many others. He spoke also of the debates in Senate, on Thursday and Friday last, which he said would continue, and intimated his intention to take further part in them— He told me that the alteration of the Constitution in 1803. of the mode of electing the President and Vice-President, had been determined upon in a Caucus, and the introduction of the amendment had been assigned to him— He had introduced it, and it was carried; but he now repented of it, and would be in favour of Mr Mills’s amendment, to repeal that Amendment, and restore the Constitution as it originally was— After I returned home Mr G. Sullivan and Mr Savage came and spent an hour with me— The rest of the Evening I was employed in writing— Mrs Adams, was very ill, confined to her bed— Her Sister Smith passed the afternoon and Evening here with her— She had at Night blisters applied behind both ears— I removed to the chamber above.
