div.p:
22. VII:15.Dr Thornton called twice at my house on the subject of the appropriation Bill, now before the Committee of Finance of the Senate— The Doctor is soliciting an appropriation for Keller to be attached to the Patent-Office, and an increase of his own Salary— He has importuned me upon this subject, till I spoke to him somewhat snappishly— And for which I will make him atonement. Mr Daniel Brent was here; also upon enquiries from the same Committee of Finance—concerning sundry items of the Appropriation Bill— I received a Letter from S. Smith Chairman of that Committee asking my attendance at their Meeting to-morrow Morning— Young Bourne was at my house and afterwards at the Office, applying again for a place— Mr Brown had engaged to take him out as his private Secretary to France; but Mr Gallatin having told him that he would have no occasion for a private Secretary, and Bourne having been taken ill at New-York, he did not go— He brought a Letter of strong recommendation from Mr Brown to the President. Mr Fuller came and conversed upon various topics; all political— Upon the vacating of Bailey’s seat, and the prospect of his re-election— We agreed in thinking that Bailey should remove without delay, and establish himself fairly in the District. Mr Fuller strongly doubts whether he will be re elected— Fuller spoke also of a Resolution of enquiry moved by Rankin of Mississippi about a payment in advance of Salary to a Florida Land-title Commissioner, who never performed the duties of the Office— It was the case of Governor Preston, all the circumstances of which must now go before Congress— He mentioned also the statement in the Intelligencer of
this Morning taken from a Virginia Newspaper, of my opinion upon the first Missouri question, which I told him was correct— At the Office General Miller came to ask again whether some Office, which would allow of his residence at home in New-England, could not be given him instead of the Government of the Arkansas territory— He mentioned the Post-Office; or the Navy Agency, at Boston, neither of which is now vacant. But if this accommodation could not be allowed him; he wished a continued leave of absence, to return and pass the Summer in New-England, for the full restoration of his health— J. A. Dix came to make enquiries whether a Minister to this Country was coming out from Buenos-Ayres; and to whom a person here, wishing to be appointed Commercial Agent to this Country could apply to obtain the place— I called at the President’s, and mentioned the applications of Governor Miller and Bourne— He consented that Miller should return to pass the Summer in New-England for the recovery of his Health; though I strongly reminded him of the objections of principle, to permitting the absence of a Governor of a Territory for such a length of time from his Post— He read to me a Message that he was about sending to Congress upon the Settlement of Governor Tompkins’s accounts— In addition to the allowances already made, the President had determined to allow him a Commission of 5 per cent upon all his expenditures; but Tompkins thinks that not enough, and insists upon going to Congress for more— Tompkins is already a memorable example of what may be done by the combined operation of gratitude, compassion, faction and political intrigue, even in the most economical republics— G. Sullivan came to the Office and shewed me a private Letter to him of the 18th. from Governor Eustis— He declines authorising the publication of Sullivan’s Letters to him concerning the claim, as I well knew he would— Sullivan now declares he will publish the Letters himself— I advised him rather to insist upon the public communication of them to the Legislature; and if Eustis should refuse that, to communicate them himself— I gave him many reasons for taking this course, concerning which he said he would consult me again— I attended the theatre this Evening, and saw the Poor Gentleman, and the Hunter of the Alps— I had never seen either of them before— The weather was very bad, and the house almost empty— The Poor Gentleman, indifferently performed was amusing to me because new— Rogers of Pennsylvania told me the Senate had this day dismissed the Caucus Question and indefinitely postponed the Constitutional Amendments 30 to 13. Mrs Adams still keeps her bed, but is recovering. Mrs Smith dined and spent the day here— Abigail S. Adams is again confined to her chamber.

23. VI:15. At ten this morning I attended at the Capitol, the Committee of Finance of the Senate—Messrs.Smith of Maryland, Macon, King of New-York, Holmes of Maine and Lowrie. They made various enquiries respecting items of Appropriation, in the Bill that has passed the House of Representatives, with the view of reducing them. The items for the relief of destitute Seamen, for intercourse with the Barbary Powers, and for the Slave Indemnity Commission, were those which they most minutely scrutinized, particularly the last— They also manifested a disposition to discontinue the appropriation of 2000 dollars a year, for a commercial agent at Paris— And there was much conversation respecting the proposed allowance of a mechanic to preserve and repair the models at the Patent Office. I was with the Committee about two hours, and then went in to the House of Representatives, where they were debating upon the tariff-Bill. It has occupied the house several weeks, and is not nearly finished— Many of the members came and conversed with me. Plumer told me that Forsyth had mentioned to him his having heard that I had made a Declaration of hostility to Crawford at the last Drawing room: and had stated that the friends of Mr Crawford had since the commencement of the present Session of Congress, changed their views, favourably towards me. That they had come here, intending to combine the interests of Mr Clay with those of Mr Crawford, but that Clay had alienated them by his conduct, and now they were more amicable towards me— That Forsyth had spoken to Plumer confidentially, but with permission to him, to communicate what he said to me— I desired Plumer to tell Forsyth, that I had never made any declaration of hostility to Mr Crawford, and felt none. But when told that I had made or agreed to a Coalition with Mr Crawford, to serve under him, I had denied it, and had said that if my friends should ultimately be compelled to vote for another man, I did not believe Crawford would be the man— J. W. Taylor read to me part of two Letters he had received from Albany; one from Mr Cramer the Senator, pressing the necessity of concentrating upon one man the opposition to Crawford— This is the Clintonian policy, and looks to Jackson— The mining and countermining upon this Presidential Election, is an admirable study of human nature— The mist into which Calhoun’s bubble broke, settles upon Jackson; who is now taking the fragments of Clinton’s party— Those of Clay, will also fall chiefly to him
and his sect and Crawford’s are now working for mine— They both consider my prospects as desperate, and are scrambling for my spoils. I can do no more than satisfy them, that I have no purchasable interest. My friends will go over to whomsoever they may prefer. Some to one; and some to another— After the adjournment of the house I went to my Office. Delafield came to take leave, and ask for certain papers— Bourne, to tell me that his life depended upon his obtaining a public Office— Captn Randall to say he was ready to start for the Havanna— And I am ready for him; but to furnish him the means for his voyage, the appropriation Act must pass— Evening at the Theatre— Saw the Honey Moon, and the Weathercock— Thayer the principal performer; and Mrs Waring— The House tolerably well filled, Chiefly by members of Congress— Mrs Adams better. Returned to my chamber.

24. VI:45.H. G. Burton of North-Carolina came this morning, to converse with me upon the same subject, of which Forsyth had spoken to Plumer— The rumour of a declaration of hostility by me, at the last Drawing Room, against Crawford. I told him I had made no declaration of hostility against Crawford, and felt none— I did not recollect having conversed with any one at the last Drawing-Room, upon the Subject; but I had said in answer to questions whether I had assented to a Coalition with Mr Crawford, in subordination to him, that no such coalition existed— That it was impossible that I should form a part of an Administration, under Mr Crawford—and that if my friends should ultimately vote for another, I did not believe Mr Crawford would be the man— Burton said that he felt very anxious for the Event of Mr Crawford’s being withdrawn— That his health was exceedingly precarious. That his life was very uncertain, and he, Burton was very anxious that in the Event of Crawford’s failure, I should have the next support of his friends. He was especially afraid of Western Politics, and of Clay— I went over the ground again with Burton, and assigned to him the decisive objections to my serving under Mr Crawford. That I could not place myself in that relation to him, with the feelings essential to a zealous and heart prompted discharge of its duties;—nor without sacrificing not only my personal standing towards Crawford, as from man to man; but also that of my own section of the Country to his— So far as it would be a sacrifice of mere personal pride, I could make it; but as that of the relative consideration of my State and Section I could not— Burton said he had told Crawford of my remarks to the same effect heretofore; to which Crawford had answered, that there was great weight in them; but that he still thought his chance for election better than mine— That, I observed was to be determined
by the event— Perhaps neither of us might prove to be the strongest. I told him further that intimations of a similar character to those that I had received from Mr Crawford’s friends, had since been made by partizans of Genl. Jackson, and had received answers substantially the same— Mr A. B. Woodward came with several additional papers in vindication of his character to be laid before the President. Mr Ames came to my house and afterwards to the Office with information that Mr Holmes, a Senator from Maine intended to oppose his nomination as Marshal for the District of Maine— He says that a person named Peter Green now here told him, not directly from Holmes but with intimation that he spoke advisedly, that if he Ames, would pledge himself to vote for Mr Crawford and support his Election, Holmes would then make no opposition— And Green told Ames, he had no doubt that Benjamin Green, Ames’s rival candidate for the Office of Marshal, had given Holmes this pledge. Now Benjamin Green of his own accord, after he knew that Ames had been nominated for Marshal, protested to me in the most explicit and earnest vows, that under every possible event he should exert all the influence that he possessed— Wherefore I do not believe that he gave Holmes any pledge to support Crawford— But to some politicians electioneering promises are like custom-house Oaths to some traders— Ames says that the whole amount of the charge against him is that during the late War he was part owner of a Schooner which went out with a double set of papers to elude capture by the British— That he could furnish proof that Holmes was at the same time concerned in vessels that furnished the British with provisions. He says that Holmes intends also to oppose the appointment of Wingate as Collector at Bath— Mr Buck, a member of the House from Vermont came with certain papers. Mr Bailey called— He proposes to go for Massachusetts the next week; and I advised him, with a view to the prospect of his re-election, to go as soon as possible— He read me extracts from several Letters received by him, and mentioned several applications for Appointments— At the Office Mr Savage came to solicit an appointment as Consul in the new Republic of Guatimala, with a Salary for a year or two— Mr Vose came to take leave— Going away, and having abandoned for the present his project for publishing a sequel to Wait’s State Papers. A Mr Slacumb came to enquire whether, there was now a Consul at
Buenos-Ayres, and finding there was not, applied for the place— General Jackson and Mr Eaton of Tennessee came to make enquiries concerning the claim—and for the papers of Reuben Kemper— I am to take the papers to the President— Evening at the Theatre— Saw John Bull, and the Woodman’s Hut— The last a Melo-dramatic Romance. Both Plays well performed— Mrs Adams better, but had a new and severe return of her illness. Letter to Prest. and Directors of Metropolis Bank.

25. VII.B. W. Crowninshield called and left with me a Letter to him from General H. A. S. Dearborn, enclosing a copy of one from him to Coll. Towson— An answer to one from Towson, canvassing for Dearborn’s influence to obtain the Election of Calhoun as Vice-President— Dearborn answers that this is impossible— That the impulse there is given for Jackson as Vice-President, and that Calhoun must be Secretary of State. Crowninshield could not wait, but said he would call upon me in a day or two again— Wyer was here, and told me Coll. Taylor of Caroline, the Senator from Virginia, had mentioned to him that there was a rumour circulated in that State, that my father had made his Will, bequeathing his Estate to a public institution, or to his native town, and that from this it was inferred that I was labouring under his displeasure, and it was producing unfavourable political impressions concerning my personal character. He said Coll. Taylor had thoughts of writing to my father about it— I told Wyer that I should be glad if Coll. Taylor would write; that my father’s conduct to me had been that of a most affectionate father; and that he had not left it to the disposal of a Will to bestow upon me my portion of his Estate— He had conveyed it to me by deed, irrevocable by himself. I stated to him the various dispositions, advantageous to me already made by my father, and his undeviating kindness to me— This utterly groundless rumour, is a new ingredient in the electioneering cauldron—what next?— Mr Tucker the Treasurer came and introduced a Mr Cabell of Virginia, a claimant under the Slave-indemnity Commission. He has furnished much of the evidence, lately collected for the Commissioners of the average value of Slaves, and is much interested in the event, he wanted some documents, supposed to be at the Department; and I referred him to Mr D. Brent— Mr Edward Livingston, a member from Louisiana, came and brought two Letters to him; one from James Hepburn at Mexico, the other from a General D’Alvimar, which he wished to have laid before the President— R. H. Bayard came for an answer to the application from L. M’Lane and himself as Executors of his father’s Will; for a half outfit as Commissioner to negotiate the Convention of 3 July 1815— I told him the application was before the President; who thought the
allowance could not be made; Mr Bayard not having gone to London, upon that mission— At the Office, G. Sullivan came, and told me that his Colleague Pearce, had determined to go before the Committee of Congress to whom the President’s Message on the Massachusetts claim should be referred, and there protest against the disavowal, which Sullivan had made of the Constitutional obstacles of the Government of Massachusetts, during the War; and that to prevent Pearce from doing this, he saw no other course than to resign, whereby their authority being joint would cease to exist— I suggested to him the alternative, of obtaining positive Instructions from Governor Eustis; but he said that Pearce would pay no regard to any Instructions— I think this hardly probable; but Pearce’s conduct has been quite extraordinary— Sullivan said that on resigning he should not immediately go home, but would remain here or go into Virginia for four or five weeks—which I conclude is with a view to await the Event of the Massachusetts Election— He spoke also of endeavouring to get the Message on the claim referred to a Committee of the whole House without sending it to any special Committee; but this would be a departure from the usual course; the attempt would be unsuccessful and probably injurious to the Claim— Company to dine— Messrs.R. Allen of Tennessee, Bartlett, R. H. Bayard, Baylies, Brent, Lot Clark, Dickerson, W. N. Edwards, Gurley, Johnston of Louisiana, Lowrie, M’Kee, M’Nair Governor of Missouri, D. H. Miller of Pennsylvania, Miller, Governor of Arkansas, Rankin, Spaight, G. Sullivan, and Tod of Pennsylvania— There had been invited, who sent excuses, Messrs. Hayward, Herkimer, Leftwich, M’Duffie, Maxcy, Noble, and Saunders— No Ladies at Table— In the Evening Mr Blunt came in, and I went with him and Sullivan to the Theatre— Saw part of the Midnight Hour; and then came away, as the Woodman’s Hut was to be repeated— Blunt came home with me, and sat an hour with me, telling me of the state of Affairs in New-York— The Clintonians have all gone over to Genl. Jackson, and the probable effect of this will be to rally a majority of the State in favour of Crawford— On retiring to bed, I found Mrs Adams, who had been better, all day, had been suddenly seized again very violently. Sent for Dr Huntt, who came and prescribed Laudanum. I got to bed about one in the Morning— Answer from Genl. Van-Ness for President & Directors of Metropolis Bank.

26. VII.Mr John S. Barbour, member of the House from Virginia, came and introduced a Mr Smith of that State— Mr Reed of Massachusetts followed and introduced a Mr Angier of Boston— Coll. R. M. Johnson of Kentucky came with Mr Savage, to urge the project of the latter to be appointed Consul General to Guatimala, with a Salary as Agent for two years— Savage left with me a written application for this, and several Letters of recommendation to be laid before the President— Genl. S. Smith Senator from Maryland brought me several Letters which he has just received from General Wilkinson at Mexico, written the last week in January and first of February, with accounts of the Military Mutinies, and political movements there at that time— And several Newspapers and printed Proclamations of the time— Smith wished them to be shewn to the President— Mr Bell, a Senator from New-Hampshire, came to recommend a Judge Durrell of that State, now here, for the appointmt. of 4th. Auditor. In addition to the merits of the man, Mr Bell dwelt much on the fact that there were no Citizens of New-Hampshire in public Office under the Executive of the United States— Genl. Van Ness called, as I had sent yesterday to request that he would— I told him that after the Letter that I had received from A. Kerr on Tuesday, I could hold no further communication with him, upon the subject of the Note, that I had endorsed for Mrs Moulton— But that I had wished to see him Van Ness, first to enquire what the President and Directors of the Metropolis Bank proposed to do; they having protested the Note; and secondly as he had been present when I had the falling out with Kerr at the Bank last Saturday; I wished to explain to him the circumstances of the case, and to say that I was ready to do everything that could justly be required of me for having endorsed my name upon the Note— I had since sending for him received his Letter informing me that the President and Directors of the Metropolis would pursue the affair no further, considering it altogether as a private concern of Mr Kerr’s, and now shewed him the papers to prove the unfairness of Kerr’s proceedings— He gave me his impressions upon the subject generally, and professed his disposition to bring the matter to an accommodation, to which I expressed my ready assent— I had received a note from the President, summoning a Cabinet Meeting at one— And found there Messrs. Calhoun, Southard and Wirt— Mr Crawford is yet Convalescent, and nearly well; but not sufficiently so to attend this day. The President had a Letter to him, from the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, M’Lane, requesting various statements respecting the transaction of business in the Auditor’s Offices, and his, the
President’s opinion, whether without public inconvenience the office of fourth Auditor may be suppressed— The same questions had already been presented in a Letter from M’Lane to the Secretary of the Treasury, upon the General Appropriation Bill— That was referred by Mr Crawford to the President, and by him after a Cabinet Meeting back to the Treasury for a Report, which, owing probably to Mr Crawford’s illness has not been made— The present application from the Chairman of a Committee, directly to the President was thought improper, and of dangerous tendency as a Precedent. The proper course to take with it, was to refer it to the Treasury Department for a Report, and that the President should request Mr M’Lane to call upon him, and personally suggest to him the necessity of giving it that direction— Whether the President should write to Mr M’Lane, inviting him to call, or send him a message by Dr Everett his private Secretary was matter of doubt; Discussion, between the President, and Committees of either house of Congress, can never be proper, and are never sought but by Chairmen of Committees disaffected to the Executive— The President also read the draft of a Message that he had prepared to send to Congress, upon the recent Correspondence with the Cherokee Chiefs, and the remonstrance and protest of the Georgia Delegation. He will send them all as Documents, with a Report from the Secretary of War, containing statements of facts; but without noticing the Georgia Protest— The draft of the Message also referring to the positive demand of the Georgians, that the Cherokees should be removed from their State by force, recommending to Congress profoundly to weigh, the obligations of the Union to Georgia, and the rights of the Indians, concluded by saying that as the refusal of the Cherokees to remove was absolute and peremptory, Congress alone were competent to authorise the employment of force—to remove them. I observed that there was so much neutrality between the parties in this, that the message might be construed into a recommendation to Congress to authorize the use of force, and if this was not intended something should be said to shew, that Georgia had no right to claim it, and that the Indians had perfect right on their side, in refusing to remove— This remark was supported by Calhoun and Southard, and the President wrote a paragraph of that import, to be inserted in the Message. I expressed the opinion also, that the Report of the Secretary of War to the President, should directly notice, and answer the charges of the Georgia Remonstrance, against the Government of the United States— Mr Southard wished that this might be done; but that the Department of State should be charged with it. Calhoun was not
inclined to undertake it, and said the Charges were of a nature which did not admit of being answered— They were charges of bad faith; of fraud and hypocrisy— The exertions of humanity, and the measures for promoting the Civilization of the Indians, were stigmatized as perfidy towards Georgia—how was it possible to answer this?— I thought it, by no means difficult to answer; but as Mr Calhoun seemed unwilling to undertake it, I did not urge it— Perhaps silence is the best answer to imputations so gross and unfounded. I had taken to the President’s various papers, and among them some relating to the discharge from imprisonment of a man named Bulloch, formerly Collector at Savannah, and to Morel the Marshal, one of his bondsmen; both men, whose characters no honest word can express. I left the papers with the President— The Meeting continued till 5— Evening at the Theatre— Saw the Heir at Law, very wretchedly performed, and did not stay to see the Woodman’s Hut, again repeated. Mrs Adams better, but still keeps her bed.

27. VII.Mr Strong of Albany came for his papers. The Committee to whom they were referred, think the evidence insufficient for them to act upon. My Son George has answered me, that he had examined the Boston Newspapers for the years 1776. 1777 and 1778 without finding a word relating to James Knowles. Strong says that he is going home; but will come again next Winter. Mr Plumer of New-Hampshire came and introduced to me judge Durrell, the person who is soliciting the appointment of fourth Auditor— Mr Allen of Massachusetts came afterwards to recommend him— Mr Seymour a Senator, and Mr Mallary a Representative from Vermont came to converse upon the Prospects of the Presidential Election— What were the views of Mr Clay; of Mr Crawford, of General Jackson; of Mr Calhoun, and of their respective friends? Since I gave so explicitly my last answers to Forsyth and Burton, that I could assent to no Coalition, to support Mr Crawford for the Presidency, and that I would form no part of an Administration under him, his Canvassers have turned to the Courtship of Mr Clay, and his friends— Mallary said that he had no doubt the main force of Clay would go to Crawford; in which I entirely concurred. I was also fully convinced that the main force of De Witt Clinton, and the stragglers of Calhoun will go over to Jackson— Seymour appeared anxious to ascertain; for whom it would be best to vote as Vice-President— I said I believed the popular feeling in New-England had already received such an impulse, that it was no longer controulable— Nor did I think it worth while, to attempt the controul of it— I was convinced it would give no dissatisfaction to General Jackson or his friends that he should be voted for as Vice-President, by those who should support me for the Presidency, and if others should carry him to the Presidency itself, we must as in every other Event of the same election acquiesce in the voice of the Nation as delivered through its constitutional organs— I told them I was very sure I had nothing to expect, and was not
willing to have any thing to ask, in the way of support to me, from any other Candidate, or his friends— I desired to stand only upon my own ground, and would not crave assistance from any other quarter. I wished my friends to vote for Jackson as Vice-President, because I thought the place suited to him, and him suited to the place. The thing was fitting in itself, and perfectly well suited to the usual geographical distribution of the two Offices,—on public principles it was unexceptionable, and I would not look further for determining motives— Mr Cheves the Commissioner, and Mr Seawell the Arbitrator upon the Slave-indemnity Commission, came to inform me of the present state of things in that board, and to advise with me concerning its future proceedings— The object of the British Commissioner and Arbitrator is to protract and ultimately to disagree, and there is doubt whether in the disagreement itself they will make a question which the umpire will be able to decide— The evidence of the average value is now closed on the part of this Government; and the British Commissioner asks of ours to propose a specific sum; intending then to propose one on his part; and then support it by documentary evidence— And as the right of offering any evidence on their part is questioned he proposes to offer his documents not as Evidence, but as argument in support of his estimate— Mr Jackson it seems considers the question of the average value, not as a point to be decided upon his oath, but as a preliminary Negotiation— Mr Cheves asked whether it would not be better ultimately to make some sacrifice upon the average value, rather than hazard the consequences of a difference upon that point— I thought it would; but not to any considerable amount. At the Office, Mr Woodward came to enquire if his papers had proved satisfactory to the President. I had not heard, and he will call again— Mr John Mason junr. came for his Commission as Secretary to the Mission to Mexico; which was delivered to him— He was appointed during the last Session of Congress. His claim to salary is under Consideration. Young Bourne came, to take leave. His project now is to follow Mr Brown to France, on the bare possibility that he may have occasion for him as his private Secretary. I thought it bare humanity to dissuade him from this Scheme, which can only involve him in greater embarrassment. Blunt came and made some enquiries concerning the sinking fund, the nature of which he did not well understand— I attended this Evening a Lecture by Dr Barber, at Tennison’s—upon Elocution— He has a theory of Accents, rather anatomical than rhetorical— He recited Satans Address to the Sun, from Milton, and Lord Chatham’s speech against the employment of Indian Savages, in the revolutionary War.

28. VI:45. Rainy day. I attended the Morning service at Mr Baker’s, and heard a Stranger, from Luke 13.6.7.8.9. [“]He spake also this parable; a certain man had a fig-tree planted in his vineyard; and he came and sought fruit thereon, and found none.— Then said he unto the dresser of the vineyard, Behold these three years I come seeking fruit on this figtree, and find none: cut it down, why cumbereth it the ground?— And he answering said unto him, Lord, let it alone this year also, till I shall dig about it, and dung it:— And if it bear fruit, well: and if not, then after that thou shalt cut it down.”— The preacher appealed to the Consciences of all his hearers, about thirty, to say whether they were not barren fig trees, and with great solemnity warned them of the consequences— This Parable, like the rest of those spoken by Jesus, was addressed to his immediate hearers, and to the People of his own age: it inculcated righteousness, and called for the fruits of repentance— But it attributes so much to the power of cultivation, for making the fig tree bear, that it is not a sound Calvinistic text: the preacher was perplexed with it, and resorted to Dr Scott’s commentary to explain it— Mr Baker gave notice that unless there should be a favourable change of the weather, there would be no afternoon service. Mr Sullivan called upon me at one, and told me that he had yesterday Morning sent to Governor Eustis his resignation as Agent for the Massachusetts Claim— He also read to me a Letter from his brother in Law, Winthrop; mentioning a conversation between his father, and Governor Eustis, respecting the publication of Sullivan’s Letters in justification of himself against the charges of W. King—to which Eustis vehemently objects— I advised Sullivan again, not to publish them in newspapers or a pamphlet, but to demand of the Governor, whether Eustis or Lathrop should be elected, that he should publicly communicate to the Legislature at their next Session the Letters— I said that considering them as answers self-defensive to charges made by W. King to the Governor of Maine: by him communicated to the Legislature of that State, and by them published, I thought the Governor of Massachusetts could not and would not refuse to communicate the defence to the Legislature of his own State, the Constituents of the Agent assailed— And if he should refuse, I would, were I in his, Sullivan’s place communicate them to the Massachusetts Legislature myself— Sullivan appeared now disposed to take this course, and I strongly dissuaded him from an immediate publication— He says it is now certain that the claim will not be acted upon during the present Session of Congress. And he has recommended to Governor Eustis to leave the subject under the direction of Mr Crowninshield— I was employed during all the leisure of this day, in bringing up the arrears of this Journal— Mrs Adams was up, great part of the day but did not leave her chamber.

29. VI:45.Mr Daniel Brent came to ask me to give my Note for him payable in sixty days at the U.S. Branch Bank, upon ample landed security— He expects to be able to pay it in four Months. I agreed to give it. Mr G. Hay came to ask for a Letter to him from Mr Cabell which he had left with me, and which I now returned— It related to the average value of Slaves— The House of Representatives struck out of the General Appropriation Bill, the amount of 2000 dollars, being the Salary for this Agency of G. Hay’s— The Senate by a large Majority restored it— And the House after two days debate, this day again agreed 113 to 51. to insist upon its being struck out— I received last Evening a Letter from Frink Roberts of Boston, announcing that he had just arrived, with a Letter from William Eustis, and asking time and place to deliver it— I appointed eleven this morning— He came twice— He wanted an Office, suitable for the support of nine Children— And introductions to the President and General Jackson whom he wished only to see— He wrote me towards Evening a Letter repeating this request, and I sent him the Introductions desired— General Miller, Governor of Arkansas Territory came with a Major Bradford and a Mr Russell of the Territory; and mentioned various complaints against the District Attorney Roane— Vexatious prosecutions; holding incompatible Offices and other like grievances— Also prosecuting and causing to be imprisoned for several Months an Indian. I told them if these complaints were made to obtain Roane’s removal, they must be preferred in writing, with reference to the proof supporting them, and so that he may have the opportunity of defending himself against them— Mr Bailey was here; and proposes leaving the City to go to Massachusetts next Thursday. Mr Buck of Vermont brought again the papers of a claim for bearing despatches from Mr Crawford in 1813. when Minister in France. The claimant isand when Buck brought the papers before, a certificate of Mr Crawford was wanted as a voucher— He had now got it, signed with initials W. H. C. scarce recognizable— Received a Note from the President calling a Cabinet Meeting at one, which I attended. Calhoun, Southard and Wirt were there— Southard said he had been told that Mr Crawford had sent the President a Message to inform him that his health was now sufficiently restored to attend Administration Meetings, if he should call him to them— The President said Mr Crawford might have said this to Dr Everett, but he had heard nothing of it. There were now two subjects for consultation— The re-nomination of Bates, as Collector at Bristol, Rhode-Island, and the Message on the compact with
Georgia, and the Cherokee titles. There were specific written charges against Bates, by D’Wolfe, the Senator from Rhode-Island, and two large bundles of papers for and against him— Owing to the illness of Mr Crawford or to his unwillingness to decide on the case; nothing has been determined at the Treasury Department, and the President after having examined all the papers himself, had yet not made up his mind on the merits— There had been a reference to the first Comptroller, Anderson— The President now sent for him, and he came— He could not make an unfavourable Report, upon the part of the complaint submitted to him; but he was competent only to pronounce on the Accounts; and not on the employment of monies: And he flinched from all superfluous responsability— Bates’s term of service expires on the fifth of next Month, and a speedy nomination to the Office is necessary— After various expedients suggested and discarded, the President wrote a Note to Mr Crawford, referring the papers to him for a Report, and suggesting that if the state of his health does not admit of his preparing it, he may charge his Chief Clerk with it— Southard asked me who had signed all Crawfords warrants throughout the Winter— I supposed himself— Southard said he had been for Months unable to write his name— On the Georgia compact and Indian Land rights, the President read a new draft of a Message, different from that of the last Meeting— In this, he very distinctly declared his opinion that the Indians cannot with Justice be removed from their Lands within the State of Georgia by force— But after setting forth all that has been done by the Government of the Union, in fulfilment of the compact; the positive refusal of the Cherokees, to cede any more of their lands upon any terms whatever, and the impossibility of devising any other means short of force to prevail upon them to go, there was a new and rather elaborate argument introduced, of the absolute necessity that the Indians should remove, West of the Mississippi. And after concluding that nothing further could be done by the Executive, there were distinct intimations that something should be done by Congress. I objected that this gave an appearance of incongruity to the message. For it was an issue between the National Executive and the Georgia Delegation; and after taking completely from under them the ground upon which they themselves stood, it gave them new ground to stand upon. It gave them the means of peremptorily claiming something further, and immediately from Congress. And if that was intended, I insisted, that the Executive ought to have some practicable project matured, and requiring nothing but the sanction of Congress to carry it into effect— The President said that no such project was prepared, nor had he any particular measure in view— Five or six years since about one third part of the Cherokee Nation were prevailed upon to surrender their Lands and remove beyond the Mississippi, and there is now in the City, a deputation from them also, complaining that they are as much
disturbed and crowded upon by the whites, as they were before their removal— I asked if it could be supposed that the deputation from the old Georgia Cherokees now here, were ignorant of this, or that they would be encouraged to abandon their old establishments for promises of a new one such as their tribesmen had found West of the Mississippi— Calhoun and Southard, inclined to support my remarks. Mr Wirt proposed the omission of certain passages directly recommending to Congress to decide upon some measure to be taken. But I thought the proposal of a measure necessarily followed from the purport of the argument, which I thought it would be best to omit altogether. The President said he would consider of it further— Mr Calhoun read the draft of his Report to the President upon the papers, which was a full statement of facts, shewing all that has been done in performance of the compact, but with scarcely an allusion to the paper signed by the Georgia delegation. The President spoke of the compact as a very unfavourable bargain to the United States, as it certainly was. Mr Calhoun thinks that the great difficulty arises from the progress of the Cherokees in civilization. They are now within the limits of Georgia about 15000 and increasing in equal proportion with the whites—all cultivators; with a representative Government; judicial Courts; Lancaster Schools, and permanent property— Ridge, Hicks, and Lowry now here, are principal Chiefs, and Ross. They write their own State papers, and reason as logically as most white diplomatists. Each of the Chiefs here named possesses from 50000 to 100000 dollars, property— One of the heaviest grievances of the Georgia Delegation is that in the Correspondence between the War Department and these Chiefs, there is a Letter from the Secretary of War to them; addressing them by the Style of “Gentlemen”— This was an inadvertency of a Clerk, overlooked by Calhoun in signing the paper, but in which the Georgians think there was deep design— The Cabinet Meeting continued till near 5— Evening at the Theatre— Clari or the Maid of Milan; an Opera by John H. Payne. Tis Marmontel’s Tale of Laurette dramatised, with the interpolation of the Garden Play in Hamlet— The dialogue is vulgar and inelegant. Without point or humour, though with efforts at both— The songs flat, and vapid; and the moral common place.— The After-piece ’Tis all a Farce, was laughable— Mrs Adams was up, all this day, but still confined to her chamber— Southard told us of Scenes on Saturday between Genl. Cocke, member from Tennessee, and Commodore Rodgers— Also of Cocke’s interviews, with W. Lee and Peter Hagner the Auditors. The Stories tell much to the disadvantage of Cocke, and are in great circulation.

30. VI:30.Mr George Hay came and delivered me a Letter, declining further to act as Agent, before the Slave indemnity Commission, and intimating that he should now urge that the necessity for an Agent was greater than it had been at any time before— But if at any time he could have removed the objection of the House of Representatives to the Agency by taking himself away, it was now too late— The appropriation Act, passed this day, with that item struck out— F. Roberts came, and thanked me for my introductions to the President and Genl. Jackson, both of whom he had seen— He told me he was going away at Twelve O’Clock; but I afterwards received two Notes from him, after my return home, so late in the Evening that I did not answer them— Mr Bulfinch came and introduced his nephew, a young Mr Apthorp of Boston, who is travelling Southward for his health. Mr James Lloyd the Senator from Massachusetts came to enquire for certain papers which he supposed to be at the Department of State, relating to prize money upon certain Tunisian vessels, taken by our Squadron in the Mediterranean in 1805.— Said he would ask of Mr Brent at the Department— The Revd. W. C. Walton came for a subscription to the third Presbyterian Church in Baltimore— Mr Nelson of Frederick who was a member of the last Congress called to make a visit. A person from the Bookseller Lucas, came to offer for sale the remaining sets of Bioren’s Edition of the United States Laws— I agreed to take 100 copies of the five Volumes, bound in Calf, at 20 dollars a set; delivered at the Department— At the Office, Mr Savage came and enquired if the President had decided upon his application for an appointment as Consul in Guatimala, with a Salary for two years— I told him the President did not think such an appointment expedient— Savage thought he could convince him by an Argument, in writing which he will accordingly prepare— Mr Peter Lanman, who has been appointed Consul at Kingston in the Island of Jamaica, came to ascertain whether under existing circumstances he could go there with expectation of being acknowledged, or even allowed to reside in the Island— I told him it was doubtful, and related to him the extraordinary proceedure of the British Government in first agreeing to receive Consuls in the West-Indies, and afterwards refusing to receive them. Coll. Bomford came for the settlement of T. Barlow’s, claim for an allowance of a quarter’s salary to return to the United States after his uncle’s decease— The Papers were at the President’s and Bomford went there for them— Mr Brent shewed me the draft of a deed of trust, that his brother William had drawn, to secure me, for the note I am to give for him— I suggested to him some necessary alterations in it, and requested him to execute the Deed to Richard Smith, Cashier of the U.S. Branch Bank, from which the money is to be borrowed— I dined at Mr Wirt’s with a company
of twenty men, among whom, the members of the Slave indemnity Commission— We had some music after dinner, by Miss Wirt—A Song, and the Guitar— G. Sullivan walked home with me— I received a Letter from Robert Swartwout at Albany, dated the 27th.— Prepare for disappointment— Mrs A.’s Evening party postponed to next Tuesday.

31. VI:45.Mr A. B. Woodward late Chief-Justice of the Michigan Territory came and told me he had seen this morning the President, who had examined the papers furnished by him, and had referred him to me, for the further communication of his wishes— Woodward was omitted from renomination at the expiration of his Commission, in consequence of remonstrances and charges against him, chiefly of intemperate habits which he had not time allowed him to refute. He now brings strong contradictory testimony, and proves that the incident most relied upon against him, that of having had wine brought to him upon the Bench, was in truth an incident of uncommon self-devotion to his duty, in going upon the bench, at a moment of convalescence, and taking one glass of medicated wine to sustain nature in exhaustion— His conduct and deportment here is much in his favour, and he said he would state to me in writing what his further wishes were— Mr Seth Knowles of Charlestown, Massachusetts and Mr Rich of Boston paid me a visit— Knowles had Letters to me from N. Silsbee and Degrand. Dr Everett called with Mr Roane; a son of the late Spencer Roane, Chief Justice of Virginia— Mr George Hay came, and proposed to continue in the Agency upon the Slave indemnity commission, without compensation for the future; an idea which he said had occurred to him, and had also been suggested to him by the President. He said that in offering his services to the claimants, he should accept no compensation for it, from them, nor of course from the public. At the Office, George Blake called to take leave— Going to-morrow morning upon his return home. Mr James Leander Cathcart came and I returned him his papers— Under two Acts of Congress within these four years he has received upwards of ten thousand dollars to not one cent of which he was entitled: and now has trumped up new and if possible more groundless claims, with a volume of writing to set them forth, and for which he comes to the Department of State. I told him with some temper, which I could not suppress that I could allow no part of those claims. He recurred to a number of precedents which were not applicable, but which gave me a new proof of the
encroaching character of all precedents— Mr Alexander Scott of Georgetown came to enquire if there was any Letter of complaint at the Department of State, against his Son, who is acting as Collector at Pensacola; and if so to demand a copy of it for his Son’s defence. I told him that I thought no such Letter had been received at the Department though I had seen Letters, complaining of the conduct of his Son— Mainly on account of a quarrel with the judge, Brackenridge. Coll. Bomford came and I approbated his voucher for settlement of the account of T. Barlow. Mr G. Sullivan sent me copies of the settlement of W. King’s account for service, as a Major General of Massachusetts Militia in the service of the United States in—1812 and 1813— He afterwards called upon me, and seemed disposed to give a different colouring to the transaction from that which appears upon its face— The document is embarrassing to him upon the ground, on which it has been placed, by his assent to the Message of the President relating to the Claim— I told him that his justification now depended entirely upon his success— Of that I had always been doubtful, and was now more doubtful than before— If he should not succeed, the claim must be carried back to the old federal grounds— Mr R. King called and told me he had a Letter from his Son Charles, of import similar to that which I received yesterday from R. Swartwout— He spoke of the paper from the Georgia Delegation. Of Benton’s, and Genl. Jackson’s opinions concerning the Indians, and of the projected nomination of Sanford, for next Governor of New-York— The Count de Menou Charge d’Affaires of France, came and mentioned that this was the day upon which by the Convention of 24 June 1822. notice should be given, of its expiration six Months in advance, unless it was to continue, with a reduction of one fourth of the discriminating duties— That the advantage of the Convention hitherto had been altogether on the side of the United States, and the French Government in consenting to its continuance, hoped it would be considered as an evidence of their friendly dispositions towards the U.S. He afterwards sent me a written note to the same effect— He spoke also of the case of Madame de la Rue, the daughter of Beaumarchais, who has been spending the winter here, endeavouring to obtain the allowance of her claim— The Committee of the House of Representatives have reported a reference to the Executive, to settle it by negotiation with the French Government, and the Report lies on the table— The Count wished me to urge any of the members of the House to have it called up and acted upon as soon as possible— He spoke of the forlorn condition of the Lady, and of the motives of benevolence which bespeak, for her a decision to relieve her from suspense— I promised if the occasion should present itself to speak to some of the members in her behalf— I attended alone the Drawing-room
at the President’s— Thinner than usual. Conversations with W. Plumer, Crowninshield, J. W. Taylor, and Burton— All accounts from Albany unfavourable to the Crawford interest; but otherwise uncertain and contradictory— Taylor’s Letter from Stewart, holds up Clay as predominant— His conversations with Moore a Calhounite transferred to Jackson— Calhoun’s game now is to unite Jackson’s supporters and mine upon him for Vice President— Look out for Breakers!

Day. Rise at 7. Write or read papers till 9–10— Breakfast— Receive visitors, and interruptedly read or write till 1–2. At the Office. Daily Mail— Current business, Call at the President’s, visitors, reading and writing till 5–6. Home to dine— Evening abroad, with company at home, or at the Theatre till 11–12. about once a week at home, writing— I have received in the course of this Month two hundred and thirty five visitors, which is an average of about eight a day. A half an hour to each visitor occupies four hours a day, but that is short of the average. The interruption to business thus incessantly repeated is distressing; but unavoidable.

lg.l: Lord of all Mercy! grant thy aid!
My Soul, for thy behest prepare,
Of bliss or bane, the varied shade
And led by thy unerring hand—
Be mine, thy purpose to fulfill;
And thine, to bless my native Land!
